page.title: 16Natural History of Brownsea
page.content: Brownsea Island has been owned by the National Trust since 1962. Prior to that it had been allowed to run wild creating interesting animal and plant communitites. One of the main features is the flourishing red squirrel population- grey squirrels have never reached the island. There are few other mammals; no badgers,foxes, weasels, stoats or other carnivorous mammals. There are Brown Rats, Shrews, Pigmey Shrews, Wood Mice, and Harvest Mice, but no Voles. There are no snakes so reptiles are represented by Lizards- Slow Worm, Common LIzard, and the rarer Sand Lizard. Common heathland and woodland plants are to be found and interesting salt and freshwater marsh communities. There is a large band of rhodendron growth down the centre of the island and daffodil fields on the south side.
